subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 3rd October 2018 - Stocks spooked as US yields jump higher
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

US MARKET WRAP – 3 October 2018: Stocks spooked as US yields jump higher

SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, crude up, dollar UP.

REAR-VIEW: US 30yr yield up by 14bps at one point, UK PM May reiterates view of free-trade deal proposal at Conservative Conference, US ADP National Employment beat, US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI jumps, Fed’s Evans expects hike in Dec, Fed's Barkin warned on hard Brexit impact on US, Fed’s Harker favoured 3 hikes in 2018, may see a 4th one in Dec, Brainard and ECB's Mersch to speak.

 AHEAD: Australian Trade Balance, US Initial Jobless Claims & Continued Jobless Claims, US Factory Orders, Banxico Interest Rate Decision, Fed's Kaplan & Quarles, ECB's Nowotny, Coeure & Rehn.

 

* ITALY: The Italian Government confirmed the 2019 deficit at 2.4% of GDP, and at 2.1% in 2020 and 1.8% in 2021; note the possibility of reducing the deficit under 2.2% and sub 2% in 2020, 2021 respectively was hinted earlier by the government. Deputy PM Di Maio also said EUR 10bln is the minimum figure for citizens income and confirmed this will be included in the budget alongside a rise in the lowest pensions and tax cuts for companies; he added there is no plan to cut the deficit more if GDP growth disappoints. As a side note, this worried investors in the European session as reports had suggested if Finance Minister Tria's forecasts were mistaken, the debt/GDP ratio could rise well above 2.4% and possibly above 3%, breaching the EU rule. Italian Economy Minister Tria later said that the government will ensure that debt falls by more in 2019 than recent years adding that the deficit will fall gradually in the years after 2019. Italy's Deputy PM Salvini also added Italy's GDP will rise at least 1.5% in 2019 and that the only certain figure is the 2019 2.4% deficit/GDP target. The EU Commission said it will assess Italy's budget once it is submitted and that they will be taking into account the Commission's economic forecasts. Later in the session, Italy's EU Affairs Minister Savona said he presented a document to the EU parliament to reassess EU monetary and fiscal policy; he told EU lawmakers there is absolutely no chance Italy will default on its debt, and Italy is nothing like Greece.

* BREXIT: UK PM May at the Conservative Party conference stuck to her Chequers plan despite not giving any explicit reference to the name; she defined her proposal a free trade deal that provides for frictionless trade in goods which would give control on money and taxes. She also said Britain is not afraid to leave the EU without a deal, adding that a no-deal would be a bad outcome for both the UK and the EU as tariffs and costly checks at borders would be introduced, noting it would be tough at first. Therefore, she urged to come together even if we do not all agree on every part of Brexit. On the UK economy, she emphasized that reducing the deficit has been painful, though she expects the debt as a share of the economy to go down. She highlighted the next challenge is to help working people with the cost of living noting the conservative answer is helping with ending austerity. On the housing market, she said the only way to fix broken market is by building more homes. Elsewhere, Irish PM Varadkar stated that UK PM May is hoping for bilateral talks but that will not happen whilst UK Brexit Minister Raab said it is not fair to say that Northern Ireland's DUP has whip in Brexit negotiations and that he will de-dramatise the Northern Ireland issue and work on technical and technological solutions.

* FED: Fed's Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) is comfortable with the expected path for the expectations of rate hikes and expects rates to be raised in December. He however noted inflation expectations in the market have not gone as much as he would like and sees negative interest rates as ‘very painful’. He was upbeat on the current state of the economy describing this momentum as a 'very mature' expansion. He noted the US fiscal policy is 'extremely pro-cyclical'. On trade, he believes the situation is 'a lot more complicated' stressing it is positive that the US has struck deal with both Canada and Mexico as this removes uncertainty for businesses. On Brexit, he noted successful negotiations would be beneficial for the US. Fed's Harker (Non-Voter, Dovish) favoured 3 rate hikes this year but could favour one more hike in December; he does not want to rush normalisation. He stated employment numbers keep surprising the Fed and thins they will eventually slow down. Fed's Barkin (Voter) did not discuss monetary policy but warned a 'hard Brexit' or a 'political crisis' are scenarios for potential shocks to the US economy. Fed's Mester (Hawk, Voter) does not see a risk inflation will pick up "precipitously" and believes gradual pace rate increases are still appropriate. She notes reaching a phase in policy where the Fed is very dependent on data. She warned US divergence from other economies could see feed back through the dollar and other markets which would have to be factored into policy.

* ADP surprised investors reporting a 230k jump in private payrolls last month which seems to have shrugged off any impact from Hurricane Florence; this was the best reading since February. Analysts at Pantheon note this is in line with the recent strength of other surveys including g the ISMs and JOLTS, though they note that ‘in months hit by both severe winter storms or hurricanes, ADP consistently is stronger than the official number’ since ADP includes names on the payroll list even if people did not receive an income in that period. As a result, they anticipate Friday’s estimate to show a temporary drop this week and thus expect 150k payrolls to be added to the economy, consensus is for 185k.

* ISM NON-MFG leaped last month indicating economic activity has strengthened in the US. The Non-Mfg Index hit a 21-year high posting at 61.6 (Prev. 60.4). Current activity, new orders and supplier delivers were also all lifted. Analysts at Wells Fargo note input prices in non-mfg are showing a few signs of easing. The Employment Index also jumped to an all-time high of 62.4 which raises Well Fargo’s NFP expectations for this week to 210k; they also note GDP growth will remain robust heading into Q4.

* SPX +0.07% at 2926, NDX +0.12% at 7637, DJI +0.21% at 26831 SECTORS: Energy +0.83%, Materials -0.76%, Industrials +0.45%, Cons Discretionary -0.43%, Cons Staples -1.06%, Healthcare -0.23%, Financials +0.81%, Tech +0.34%, Telecoms +0.27%, Utilities -1.23%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was the biggest gainer -ATOW- in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq on the back of the casino industry as whole gaining. SVB Financial (SIVB) another big gainer, benefitting from a Barclays price target rise and financial sector gains as whole. Xilinx (XLNX) pushed up the Nasdaq after price target raises at BMO and Credit Suisse. Energy names such as HollyFrontier (HFC) and Valero Energy (VLO) traded higher as did the wider energy sector, despite the bigger than expected build in EIA data. AMD (AMD) and Edwards Lifesciences (EW) continued their tumble from yesterday making them the biggest losers on the day. (TSLA) pushed down on the day, also Hudson Bay Capital announced they were short on the stock. Other losers included the REIT, Weyerhaeuser (WY) and oil co. Baker Hughes (BHGE).

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD 1.18 HIGHER AT USD 76.41/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 1.89 HIGHER AT USD 86.29/BBL. Crude was under pressure on Wednesday after Russia/Saudi Arabia suggested that OPEC and its partners has a buffer of spare capacity to offset declines in Iranian/Venezuelan output/exports, as well as a bearish inventory report out of the DOE. Saudi Arabia’s energy minister Al Falih said the nation’s current rate of production was running at a record 10.7mln BPD, and said that level will tick higher in November. Russia’s Putin, meanwhile, said that Russia has the capacity to boost output by 200k-300k BPD, adding that he would be happy to see crude prices between $65-75/bbl. Libya’s NOC also suggested it may be able to raise output from current levels around 1.25mln BPD. “It looks as though Saudi Arabia and Russia are both pumping more freely, which works both as a response to the likely impact of US sanctions on Iranian supply and as a more practical business-oriented response to higher prices,” Citi said, “if the market can accept the increased volumes at the higher price level, both the Saudis and Russians are ready to ring the cash register.” There was further downside in crude after weekly inventory data showed a larger than expected build (7.975mln vs an expected 1.132mln), Cushing stocks rose 1.699mln, gasoline stocks drew down by 459k against an expected build of 1.316mln, while distillate stocks slipped by 1.75mln in line with the expected draw of 1.672mln. However, in the aftermath of the release, crude pared back its losses amid reports of Yemen missiles fired at Saudi soldiers; with WTI returning back to consolidate above $75/bbl, while Brent made its way back to the $85/bbl region it has been consolidating at this week. In later comments, Russian Energy Minister Novak said there is always a risk of oil prices rising too quickly, noting oil is ‘a bit too high’ already.

US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 4+ TICKS HIGHER AT 118.26. Treasury yields ticked higher on Wednesday, and the curve bear-steepened, underpinned by solid ADP employment data ahead of this week’s official payrolls, as well as an encouraging non-manufacturing ISM report. Amid this news, traders continued to cite evidence of wage pressures in the US, after Amazon (AMZN) announced it would raise minimum wages for its employees. The probability of an FOMC rate hike in December also edged higher as Treasuries were sold. Front-end yields found fresh decade+ highs, while 10-year yields rose to the highest since July 2011, and 30-year yields rose to the highest since October 2014. Major curve spreads were wider, with 2s10s rising to 30bps (+5bps), 2s30s above 45bps (+5.6bps), 5s30s to 29bps (+25.7bps) , though 10s30s was only modestly steeper.

* DXY: Back on a firmer footing, with the index rebounding from sub-95.300 levels extending to over 95.750 at best in wake of upbeat ADP and non-manufacturing ISM surveys. Note, the former beat on the headline front and was supplemented by a back-month upgrade (albeit relatively small), while the latter also surprised on the upside with a strong jobs component that all bodes well for the official monthly BLS employment report on Friday.

* NZD, AUD: Extending recent losses and underperformance on increasingly bearish chart impulses, ongoing global trade concerns and in the case of the Aud in particular data as well (building permits plunged much more than expected in August). Aud/Usd slipped just below 0.7150 to test tech support around 0.7142, as big option expiries at 0.7190 (1.2 bn) kept upside attempts capped ahead of 0.7200. Ahead, a speech from RBA assistant Governor Ellis may provide some fresh/independent direction, while the Aud/Nzd cross straddles 1.0900 and Kiwi hovers near 0.6550 vs its US peer.

* CHF: Another G10 laggard vs the Greenback and other counterparts, with the Franc around 0.9900 and around 1.1400 vs the Eur even though the single currency suffered more Italian budget related angst.

* JPY: Relatively rangebound vs the Usd between113.50-114.30 on the wide, and lacking any real specific drivers on the Jpy side, as a combination of strong chart levels and hefty supply/offers kept the headline pair largely in check (although rebounding US Treasury yields and a slowdown in Japan’s services PMI to near 50.0 may well have had some underlying influence).

* EUR, CAD: The single currency fluctuated from circa 1.1525 to 1.1595 on a stream of Italian budget headlines (vs a restrained 1.2805-45 Loonie range) and then retreated below 1.1515 heading to the US close. The Eur was elevated or simply relieved after reports suggesting that Italy’s coalition could set sights lower on 2020 and 2021 deficits.

* GBP: As noted above, the exception to the rule as the Pound shrugged off a slightly sub-forecast UK services PMI to trade just below 1.3000 vs the Dollar and just below 0.8900 vs the Eur in wake of reports that a more detailed blueprint for the Irish border back-stop may be published soon. Note, PM May raised some eyebrows with her ‘choreographed’ conference arrivals and for not mentioning the Chequers White Paper during the closing speech.

Another G10 laggard vs the Greenback and other counterparts, with the Franc only just holding above 0.9900 and back down under 1.1400 vs the Eur even though the single currency suffered more Italian budget related angst.

JPY

Relatively rangebound vs the Usd between113.50-114.05 on the wide, and lacking any real specific drivers on the Jpy side, as a combination of strong chart levels and hefty supply/offers kept the headline pair largely in check (although rebounding US Treasury yields and a slowdown in Japan’s services PMI to near 50.0 may well have had some underlying influence).

EUR/CAD

Both looking to end Wednesday’s EU session pretty flat vs the Usd, but this hardly tells the full story for the single currency that fluctuated from circa 1.1525 to 1.1595 on a stream of Italian budget headlines (vs a restrained 1.2805-45 Loonie range). The Eur was elevated or simply relieved after early reports suggesting that Italy’s coalition could set sights lower on 2020 and 2021 deficits (2.2% and 2% respectively, or even a tad less per 5-Star sources), but subsequently deflated by comments implying no figures have been agreed apart from 2.4% for next year. Moreover, Di Maio is holding out for at least Eur10 bn for the citizens income and will not commit to other measures beyond growth for debt reduction. All will apparently be revealed shortly (parliament submission said to be after 4 pm London time), or not as other Government sources revert to nothing out today!

GBP

As noted above, the exception to the rule as the Pound shrugged off a slightly sub-forecast UK services PMI to trade back above 1.3000 vs the Dollar and well over 0.8900 vs the Eur in wake of reports that a more detailed blueprint for the Irish border back-stop may be published soon. Note, PM May raised some eyebrows with her ‘choreographed’ conference arrivals and for not mentioning the Chequers White Paper during the closing speech.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 3rd October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italian Economy Minister tries to tame budget excesses ahead of key meeting
  • BTPs firm but off peaks as Di Maio maintains citizens income demands
  • Looking ahead, highlight include, US services PMI, US ADP, ISM non-mfg, Fed’s Barkin, Harker, Bullard, Brainard and Mester

ASIA

Asian stocks traded choppy following a mixed lead from Wall St. where the Dow hit all-time highs aided by gains in Intel shares, while Nasdaq was pressured by large-cap tech names tumbling over a percent. ASX 200 (+0.3%) outperformed as miners boosted the index, while Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) was weighed on by auto names with Honda and Toyota falling 3% and 2% respectively, while the index was also mirroring currency fluctuations throughout the session. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) traded lower amid weakness in financial names and as the tech sector failed to support the index following Tencent’s plans to IPO it’s music arm in the US, in what could be one the biggest IPOs to date. Meanwhile, mainland China and South Korea were shut due to public holidays.

NEC Director Kudlow said US and China keep talking about trade, while the White House Advisory said China has not made a serious enough effort at appeasing the US. (Newswires)

Tokyo Financial Exchange plans to expand trading to Hong Kong and Taiwan. (Newswires)

Japan Nikkei Services PMI (Sep) 50.2 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.5) – 2 year low. (Newswires)
Japan Nikkei Composite PMI (Sep) 50.7 (Prev. 52.0)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May is reportedly under pressure to set out a timetable for her departure after Cabinet ministers said it was now a question of “when, not if” she stands down as Prime Minister. Sources suggest that if she refuses to step down, plans will be drawn up to force her departure before the next general election. (Telegraph)

UK PM May said in the event of a no-deal Brexit, WTO tariffs would come into effect. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said we can expect to have a deal in time for Christmas and the UK must get a deal in November otherwise it’s too short on time for legislative time-frame. (Newswires)

British Cabinet Office Minister Lidington states that the government will present more thorough proposals on the Irish backstop very soon. (Newswires)

Conservative MP James Duddridge submitted a letter to 1922 committee calling on Theresa May to resign, claiming he has “not met a single MP who thinks she will lead us into another election” (Sky)

The Italian Government confirmed the 2019 deficit at 2.4% of GDP, and said they may reduce 2020, 2021 to under 2.2% and sub 2% respectively. The Deputy PM also said that EUR 10bln is minimum figure for citizen income, and added there is no plan to cut the deficit more if GDP growth disappoints. Italian Economy Minister Tria later said that the Govt. will ensure that debt falls by more in 2019 than recent years adding that the deficit will fall gradually in the years after 2019 (Newswires)

EU Commission says it will assess Italy's budget once it is submitted; they will be taking into account Commission's economic forecasts. (Newswires)

Turkish CPI YY Jul 24.52% (Prev. 17.9%)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Sep) 54.7 vs. Exp. 54.7 (Prev. 54.7)

EU Markit Comp Final PMI (Sep) 54.1 vs. Exp. 54.2 (Prev. 54.2)

German Markit Comp Final PMI (Sep) 55.0 vs. Exp. 55.3 (Prev. 55.3)

German Markit Services PMI (Sep) 55.9 vs. Exp. 56.5 (Prev. 56.5)

French Markit Comp PMI (Sep) 54.0 vs. Exp. 53.6 (Prev. 53.6)

French Markit Services PMI (Sep) 54.8 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.3)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Sep) 53.9 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.3)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Evans says he is comfortable with the expected path for the expectations of a rate hike, is comfortable with a December rate hike. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo is to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jung Un on Sunday. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities started the day on the front foot after the early morning risk tone benefited from Italy confirming the debt/GDP target from 2020 at 2.2% vs. the originally quoted 2.4%. This, however, reversed course after the details from their budget proposal said a “minimum” of EUR 10bln is to be set aside for citizens income and that there are no plans to alter the deficit if GDP growth disappoints.

This has led to investors repeating concerns over fiscal irresponsibility and the possibility of debt/GDP rising over 3% should GDP growth forecasts not come in line. This hit market sentiment, with equities now flat after having been in positive territory in the early morning.

Note, that the DAX is closed for trading on this session for German Unity day.

Norsk Hydro and Tesco are leading the losses in Wednesday’s session. The Scandinavian company is being hit by the ceasing of operations at their Alunorte site in Brazil. Tesco is struggling after reporting earnings wherein profit missed expectations.

FX

EUR/GBP - Clear G10 outperformers, or at least bucking the overall trend of losses vs the USD, with the single currency bouncing firmly from near 1.1500 lows towards the big figure above following reports that the Italian Government is aiming to cut 2020 and 2021 deficits from an initial 2.4%, which still stands for next year, and perhaps even below 2.2% and 2% respectively. However, Eur/Usd has eased back awaiting confirmation of the more compliant budget plan, as Deputy PM Di Maio undermines some of the good will/relief by stating that the minimum amount for citizens income should be set at Eur10 bn. Attention now turns to another coalition party convene in Rome, and from a technical standpoint the headline pair faces resistance just above 1.1600, if that level is breached, such as the 50 DMA (1.1607) and a 38.2% Fib (1.1624). Meanwhile, Cable is retesting the 1.3000 handle awaiting UK PM May’s keynote address to close the Tory Party conference amidst reports from the DUP that a more detailed Irish back-stop proposal will be unveiled soon, and not that deterred by a marginal services PMI miss.

AUD/NZD - The major losers and retreating further from Tuesday’s recovery highs, with the Aud hit by significantly weaker than expected Aussie building approvals overnight and only just holding above 0.7150 ahead of a speech from RBA’s Ellis and with heavy option expiry interest at the 0.7190 strike (1.2 bn) also in the mix. The Kiwi has fallen in sympathy, but also in wake of yet another sharp decline in GDT auction prices to circa 0.6560.

CAD/JPY/CHF - All down against the Greenback, but within recent ranges as the Loonie keeps its head above 1.2850 and Jpy over 114.00 and large offers said to be sitting between 114.20-60 and Franc continues to meander within a 0.9835-70 band.

EM - Inflation vibes have impacted the Lira and Rand, with Turkish CPI far exceeding forecasts and catapulting to 24%+ y/y and Usd/Try rallying to almost 6.1000 in response from just under 6.0000 pre-data, while Usd/Zar has rebounded from sub-14.2900 to 14.3500+ in wake of an SARB warning about inflation overshooting the 6% target. However, the Lira may yet regain traction if measures to combat inflation are deemed credible/successful and the courts decide to release US Pastor Brunson after the latest appeal.

COMMODITIES

The source report story suggesting Russia and Saudi Arabia are to boost oil output in December hit the oil market, which started in the green off the back of yesterday’s smaller than expected build in API crude stocks. The crude complex is now flat as suggestions of increased supply halted Brent’s advance over the USD 85/BBL with the benchmark now hovering just below the big figure.

The Iraqi Energy Minister said that they will assess increased OPEC output in November.

In the metals scope, gold is unchanged after having risen by over 1% in the previous session. The biggest mover in the commodities scope can be found in aluminium, which has rallied to over 5 week highs after Norsk Hydro announced the cessation of operations at their Alunorte site in Brazil, stoking the flames of supply concerns for the industrial metal.

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session - Roman budget division leads to mixed markets ahead of coalition convene -  3rd October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities started the day on the front foot after the early morning risk tone benefited from Italy confirming the debt/GDP target from 2020 at 2.2% vs. the originally quoted 2.4%. This, however, reversed course after the details from their budget proposal said a “minimum” of EUR 10bln is to be set aside for citizens income and that there are no plans to alter the deficit if GDP growth disappoints.

This has led to investors repeating concerns over fiscal irresponsibility and the possibility of debt/GDP rising over 3% should GDP growth forecasts not come in line. This hit market sentiment, with equities now flat after having been in positive territory in the early morning.

Note, that the DAX is closed for trading on this session for German Unity day.

Norsk Hydro and Tesco are leading the losses in Wednesday’s session. The Scandinavian company is being hit by the ceasing of operations at their Alunorte site in Brazil. Tesco is struggling after reporting earnings wherein profit missed expectations.

FX

EUR/GBP - Clear G10 outperformers, or at least bucking the overall trend of losses vs the USD, with the single currency bouncing firmly from near 1.1500 lows towards the big figure above following reports that the Italian Government is aiming to cut 2020 and 2021 deficits from an initial 2.4%, which still stands for next year, and perhaps even below 2.2% and 2% respectively. However, Eur/Usd has eased back awaiting confirmation of the more compliant budget plan, as Deputy PM Di Maio undermines some of the good will/relief by stating that the minimum amount for citizens income should be set at Eur10 bn. Attention now turns to another coalition party convene in Rome, and from a technical standpoint the headline pair faces resistance just above 1.1600, if that level is breached, such as the 50 DMA (1.1607) and a 38.2% Fib (1.1624). Meanwhile, Cable is retesting the 1.3000 handle awaiting UK PM May’s keynote address to close the Tory Party conference amidst reports from the DUP that a more detailed Irish back-stop proposal will be unveiled soon, and not that deterred by a marginal services PMI miss.

AUD/NZD - The major losers and retreating further from Tuesday’s recovery highs, with the Aud hit by significantly weaker than expected Aussie building approvals overnight and only just holding above 0.7150 ahead of a speech from RBA’s Ellis and with heavy option expiry interest at the 0.7190 strike (1.2 bn) also in the mix. The Kiwi has fallen in sympathy, but also in wake of yet another sharp decline in GDT auction prices to circa 0.6560.

CAD/JPY/CHF - All down against the Greenback, but within recent ranges as the Loonie keeps its head above 1.2850 and Jpy over 114.00 and large offers said to be sitting between 114.20-60 and Franc continues to meander within a 0.9835-70 band.

EM - Inflation vibes have impacted the Lira and Rand, with Turkish CPI far exceeding forecasts and catapulting to 24%+ y/y and Usd/Try rallying to almost 6.1000 in response from just under 6.0000 pre-data, while Usd/Zar has rebounded from sub-14.2900 to 14.3500+ in wake of an SARB warning about inflation overshooting the 6% target. However, the Lira may yet regain traction if measures to combat inflation are deemed credible/successful and the courts decide to release US Pastor Brunson after the latest appeal.

FIXED INCOME

Yet more conflicting reports from Italy on the budget front, with 5-Star sources suggesting even more deficit containment after 2019 and Economy Minister Tria still trying to tow the EU fiscal line, but Di Maio pushing for a minimum spend of Eur10 bn on citizens income, while implying no automatic measures to cut the debt load if growth is not strong enough to ensure a reduction. In sum, a lot riding on, and still uncertain ahead of the upcoming  meeting in Rome, but a sharp reversal in BTPs from best levels to 120.81 at one stage (-21 ticks vs +141 ticks earlier), while Bunds pared more of their arrears to only -6 ticks at 159.46 vs -53 ticks at 158.99, which was also a tech support level. Elsewhere, a more marked rebound in Gilts from -23 ticks to +6 ticks at a new 121.38 Liffe intraday high, with perhaps additional impetus from the UK services PMI and now awaiting PM May around 11.45BST. Turning to US Treasuries, futures remain hemmed near the base of overnight ranges and the curve is steeper in advance of a packed agenda including data and a lot more Fed speak after repeated his satisfaction with market rate expectations and a final one this year in December.

COMMODITIES

The source report story suggesting Russia and Saudi Arabia are to boost oil output in December hit the oil market, which started in the green off the back of yesterday’s smaller than expected build in API crude stocks. The crude complex is now flat as suggestions of increased supply halted Brent’s advance over the USD 85/BBL with the benchmark now hovering just below the big figure.

The Iraqi Energy Minister said that they will assess increased OPEC output in November.

In the metals scope, gold is unchanged after having risen by over 1% in the previous session. The biggest mover in the commodities scope can be found in aluminium, which has rallied to over 5 week highs after Norsk Hydro announced the cessation of operations at their Alunorte site in Brazil, stoking the flames of supply concerns for the industrial metal.

content: UK debt and STIR contracts continue to take their cues from elsewhere in the absence of anything concrete on the final and most divisive Brexit issues, and the early Liffe tone is bearish as expected given latest less contentious fiscal developments in Italy. Gilts have traded between 121.09-26 since the open vs yesterday’s 121.32 settlement, with the 3 month strip flat to 2 ticks adrift at worst, as Bunds pare some of their losses to 23 ticks at 159.29 vs -53 ticks at the Eurex low and BTPs fail to sustain momentum above 122.00. In terms of Wednesday’s domestic agenda, September’s services PMI is due and like manufacturing and construction surveys forecast to reveal slower activity, but recall that the latter 2 were mixed. Also on the slate ahead, Gbp3 bn 2024 issuance that is building some concession for Thursday's auction, albeit largely on the aforementioned external factors.

content: The pattern remains the same for core Eurozone debt vs Italian/peripheral paper, and latest reports from Rome about a climbdown on budget deficits after 2019, tapering to 2% by 2021 have prompted a reasonable relief rally in BTPs to the detriment of Bunds. Ranges so far for the respective 10 year benchmarks are 121.58-122.43 and 158.99-159.20 vs Tuesday’s 121.02 and 159.52 closes, with the corresponding yield spread converging through 300 bp accordingly. Ahead, services and composite PMIs ahead of retail sales, but it’s still almost if not quite all about Italy in the run up to another meeting before formal presentation to parliament, and then the ensuing EU verdict after October 15.

**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded choppy following a mixed lead from Wall St. where the Dow hit all-time highs aided by gains in Intel shares, while Nasdaq was pressured by large-cap tech names tumbling over a percent. ASX 200 (+0.3%) outperformed as miners boosted the index, while Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) was weighed on by auto names with Honda and Toyota falling 3% and 2% respectively, while the index was also mirroring currency fluctuations throughout the session. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) traded lower amid weakness in financial names and as the tech sector failed to support the index following Tencent’s plans to IPO it’s music arm in the US, in what could be one the biggest IPOs to date. Meanwhile, mainland China and South Korea were shut due to public holidays.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 3rd October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italy are said to seek cuts in their 2021 and 2020 deficit/GDP ratio to 2.0% and 2.2% respectively from 2.4%
  • EUR immediately caught a bid as the reports signal a potential compromise from Italy. Asian stocks traded choppy following a mixed lead from Wall St.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK and US services PMI, US ADP, ISM non-mfg, ECB’s Mersch, Fed’s Evans, Barkin, Harker, Bullard, Brainard and Mester

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded choppy following a mixed lead from Wall St. where the Dow hit all-time highs aided by gains in Intel shares, while Nasdaq was pressured by large-cap tech names tumbling over a percent. ASX 200 (+0.3%) outperformed as miners boosted the index, while Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) was weighed on by auto names with Honda and Toyota falling 3% and 2% respectively, while the index was also mirroring currency fluctuations throughout the session. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) traded lower amid weakness in financial names and as the tech sector failed to support the index following Tencent’s plans to IPO it’s music arm in the US, in what could be one the biggest IPOs to date. Meanwhile, mainland China and South Korea were shut due to public holidays.

NEC Director Kudlow said US and China keep talking about trade, while the White House Advisory said China has not made a serious enough effort at appeasing the US. (Newswires)

Tokyo Financial Exchange plans to expand trading to Hong Kong and Taiwan. (Newswires)

Japan Nikkei Services PMI (Sep) 50.2 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.5) – 2 year low. (Newswires)
Japan Nikkei Composite PMI (Sep) 50.7 (Prev. 52.0)

UK

UK PM May is reportedly under pressure to set out a timetable for her departure after Cabinet ministers said it was now a question of “when, not if” she stands down as Prime Minister. Sources suggest that if she refuses to step down, plans will be drawn up to force her departure before the next general election. (Telegraph)

UK PM May said in the event of a no-deal Brexit, WTO tariffs would come into effect. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said we can expect to have a deal in time for Christmas and the UK must get a deal in November otherwise it’s too short on time for legislative time-frame. (Newswires)


EU

Italy are said to seek cuts in their 2021 and 2020 deficit/GDP ratio to 2.0% and 2.2% respectively from 2.4%. (Corriere della sera/) Note: Previously, the Italian government set the deficit/GDP target at 2.4% for each year from 2019 to 2021.

Italian deputy PM Di Maio confirmed the outlines of the 2019 budget, he reiterated the 2.4% deficit-GDP and the budget will include EUR 10bln for "Citizen's Income". (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte said the budget is aimed at accelerating the fall in the debt/GDP ratio over the coming three years, while Italian house budget committee president Borghi said Italy needs its own currency. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he does not think President of EU Commission Juncker like the US very much, while he added EU was set to take advantage of the US. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets reacted quickly to reports that Italy was seeking a cut to their 2021 deficit/GDP ratio to 2.0% from 2.4%. EUR immediately caught a bid as the reports signal a potential compromise from Italy. The EUR strength weighed more on the Japanese currency than the USD with EUR/JPY and EUR/USD spiking higher by 82 pips and 53 pips respectively. DXY fell to session lows while USD/JPY rose just over 20 pips. Elsewhere, AUD experienced weakness earlier in the session amid a substantial miss in the Australian building approvals with NZD/USD moving lower in sympathy.

Australian Building Approvals (Aug) M/M -9.4% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. -5.2%)
Australian Building Approvals (Aug) Y/Y -13.6% vs. Exp. -2.5% (Prev. -5.6%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said a downward yield curve could signal that Fed policy is tight and policy is not that tight at the moment. He said trade tariffs could increase prices but US is not yet seeing effects from trade policy. Powell added gradual rates are meant to balance risks and there is a "remarkably positive outlook" on inflation and employment. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Dove, Non-voter) said he is happy with one more rate hike this year in December, base case is two next year. He is hopeful the Fed can raise rates to neutral without inverting the yield curve and the US economy is at or past full employment, while he said his view that US GDP will grow at 3% this year, 2.5% next year as fiscal stimulus fades. In regards to oil, he sees more upside risk to prices. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities trade mostly higher with outperformance in precious metals amid a subdued USD where gold found a firmer footing over USD 1200/oz and silver rose almost a percent. WTI and Brent are relatively flat following a muted reaction to the narrower-than-expected build in API crude stocks as the oils take a breather near 4-year highs.

Russian Energy Minister said he is in favour of Iran maintaining its position in the oil market and said for now OPEC and non-OPEC are operating on a case by case basis. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said oil prices seem a little high. (Newswires)

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (28 Sep) +0.907M vs. Exp. +2.000M (Prev. +2.903M) (Newswires)
US API Weekly Gasoline Stocks (28 Sep) -1.703mln (Exp. +1.300mln, Prev. +0.949mln)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo is to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jung Un on Sunday. (Newswires)

US

Action in the Treasury complex was dictated by developments on the 2019 budget over in Italy which led to a steeper yield curve as the Italy/German spread widened above 300bps. The complex dipped later in the session after Comcast launched a 12-part dollar bond to fund its USD 27bln acquisition of Sky; subsequently some flattening was seen across the yield curve. Most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve were yields were higher by c.3bps. 2s10 s and 2s30s were narrower by c.2bps at settlement. US T-note futures (Z8) settles 4+ ticks higher at 118-26.

US President Trump said there seems to be great support for the trade deal in Congress, while Senator Cornyn said the Senate may lack votes to approve the USMCA and the earliest vote could occur after November elections and could slip until next Congress. (Newswires)

Mexican Steel Chamber said if no solution can be found for the US steel and aluminium tariffs, Mexico should impose reciprocal measures on US steel imports. (Newswires)

New York State Taxation Department spokesperson said they are reviewing fraud allegations against US President Trump reported by the NYT. While comments from the White house stated the NYT article on US President Trump is "misleading" and added "the IRS reviewed and signed off these transactions"

subject: BoJ says Japan's output gap rose to the highest level since 2007
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Choppy trade for Asia following a mixed lead from Wall St.
content: Asian stocks traded choppy following a mixed lead from Wall St. where the Dow hit all-time highs aided by gains in Intel shares, while Nasdaq was pressured by large-cap tech names tumbling over a percent. ASX 200 (+0.3%) outperformed as miners boosted the index, while Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) was weighed on by auto names with Honda and Toyota falling 3% and 2% respectively, while the index was also mirroring currency fluctuations throughout the session. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) traded lower amid weakness in financial names and as the tech sector failed to support the index following Tencent’s plans to IPO it’s music arm in the US, in what could be one the biggest IPOs to date. Meanwhile, mainland China and South Korea were shut due to public holidays.

PRE-MARKET INDIA STOCK NEWS: The incoming IL&FS (ILFS IS) board may look at structured deals to pay back investors and lenders
content:
INDIA:

Reliance Industries (RIL IS) – Co. has initiated talks to acquire Hathway Cable & Datacom (HATH IS) in an attempt to speed up the commercial launch of its GigaFiber high-speed internet. (ET)

DR. Reddy’s Labs (DRRD IS) – Co’s wholly owned subsidiary Promius Pharma has sold its rights of Clodem cream. (ET)

IL&FS (ILFS IS) – The incoming board may look at structured deals to pay back investors and lenders. Two people familiar with the situation said there are buyers for assets. (ET)

Reliance Communications (RCOM IS) – Co. has blamed the Department of Telecoms for creating hurdles in the Co.’s bid to sell spectrum to Reliance Jio, which prevented the Co. from paying off its settlement amount to Ericsson. (ET)

 

YESTERDAY'S NEWS

IL&FS (ILFS IS) – Indian government wins a court approval to take control of Co. The new board consists of 6 members who are to meet before October 8th to elect a chairman. (Newswires)

Housing Development Finance (HDFC IS) – Co. has increased its retail prime lending rate by 10bps ahead of the RBI interest rate decision on Friday. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

- US President Trump said India is ready to negotiate a trade deal. (Newswires)

- RBI is to inject INR 360bln in October to meet the festival season demand for funds. (ET)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: EUR strength sends a ripple across FX markets
content:
Asian stocks trade mixed following a similar picture painted on Wall St. where the Dow hit all-time highs aided by gains in Intel shares, while Nasdaq was pressured by large-cap tech names falling over a percent. ASX 200 (+0.2%) outperforms as miners boost the index, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) was initially weighed on by auto names with Honda and Toyota falling 3% and 2% respectively, however, the recent currency effect has lifted the index from intraday lows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch) trades little changed after a negative open and mainland China is still away on holiday.

FX markets reacted quickly to reports that Italy was seeking a cut to their 2021 deficit/GDP ratio from 2.4% to 2.0%. EUR immediately caught a bid as the reports signal a potential compromise from Italy. EUR strength weighed more on the Japanese currency than the USD with EUR/JPY and EUR/USD spiking higher by 82 pips and 53 pips respectively, while USD/JPY rose around 20 pips, however DXY saw session lows. Elsewhere, AUD/USD earlier reacted to a substantial miss in M/M building approvals with NZD/USD moving in sympathy.
